segments.text: And all the wild ones, all jungle.
And we'd see kangaroos, lots of them.
And somebody had a horse out there, and this horse had a, its back looked like it was broken or something.
It had a, you know, a dip like this.
And we knew it was the G.I.
that had gone over there with a paint, a can of white paint, and for twenty grand.
Remember there was a race car that was twenty grand?
And we just said, boy, someone's been up there ahead of us.
And so finally,
We went to Brisbane, Brisbane, Australia.
Well, we didn't stop there.
We had to go farther up, and we noticed that the black G.I.s, they either were
They had them fixing up pontoon bridges to get across some river or body of water.
And the other truck drivers were water master.
And boy, I tell you, there was a shortage of food, a shortage of everything in Australia.
So the black drivers, you know, they started to meet some of the women there.
And they used this when they found out that they needed this.
We'd go over there and somebody had brooms that weren't available and canned food.
And so it wasn't long before those black guys were fraternizing with the women.
And we went to a movie.
It was only at night.
Couldn't go any daytime.
And went to see a black GI with a white woman.
And the woman would have had a baby.
And they were sitting there, and they had the baby covered so nobody could see that it was black, you know.
But mixed up with that, I mean, hey, that's the way it goes.
And we didn't make too.
So then we got to Townsville, Australia.
And that was our base.
And so we had a supply depot there, and it came over from Kelly.
It was the fourth air depot.
They had all kind of supplies, you know.
By that I mean they had tools, carpenter's tools, anything that was needed to set up a camp, pipe, fittings, this kind of thing.
And so it was pretty good.
And you were in the Army Air Corps.
That's right.
Officially.
United States Army Air Corps.
And how long were you all in Australia?
I think it was about a year.
And then where?
We moved up to Port Moresby in New Guinea.
In New Guinea.
And how long there?
Well, we kept moving.
We were there at Moresby maybe six or eight months.
And then we moved on to Dubbedura and to the Markham Valley down toward L.A.
L.A.E.
L.A.E.
But we didn't go to L.A.
Instead we went north to Hollandia.
New Guinea is divided Papua on the bottom half and Dutch New Guinea at the top.
So it was
It was just a supply organization because we were handling small arms and also we were taking ammunition.
And we had to set up ammunition dumps.
So you're down there in the South Pacific through the end of the war?
Oh, yes.
All right.
Yes.
So after there, MacArthur had ordered a new move, come out
And we went to Biak, B-I-A-K. And there was a Japanese bastion, if you will.
And there was a lot of caves.
And they would use P-38s and P-40s to strafe those holes or these openings, see, because they'd bring out their cannon.
and they fired and then they cut it back inside, you see.
So we had to use those planes because we couldn't climb up there.
It was too steep.
So we were out there on Biak setting up a bomb dump.
I remember this because that's when we started getting opposition.
We had to set up revetments.
We had bulldozers in our company, so we had to put up revetments to prevent the ammunition to blow up because of a fire.
Okay?
And we were working 24 hours a day.
And at night we had some portable lamps.
And we knew that the Japanese were watching us.
And so at night the Japanese would come out, because MacArthur was bypassing some of those islands.
And those Japanese stragglers were, they were starving.
and they'd sneak into our camp area.
And we had our laundry on the line, next morning it was gone.
And we had a tent where we were storing canned goods, and we knew somebody had been here.
So we'd lay for them at night, and we never could catch them.
And even though
The lights were, the moon, there was plenty of light.
It was almost like early morning.
You could see.
Our orders were, it says, when you retire, you stay in your tent, you don't go out, or the sentries, they're going to fire on you.
Well, nothing really happened that would, you know, when we got any injuries on our side.
So after BIAC, there was a place called Wewak, and that was a strong base.
of Japanese.
So MacArthur figured, hey, we can take Wewak.
We're going to lose some people.
So what we do is just bypass them and isolate them.
Okay.
I want to back up on this one something.
The Japanese, this was in March of 1943.
The Japanese wanted to
come into New Guinea and take it over.
And the plan was the Japanese wanted to take over Port Moresby and then use that as a Japanese base to jump and take over Australia.
And General Kenny says, no way.
And MacArthur agreed with him.
I'm talking about General George Kenny.
He was a little guy, but he knew
He knew his business.
So he had reconnaissance planes flying through squalls, through storms, and to see them.
And over, I don't know how far it was, but there was a big base named Rabaul, R-A-B-A-U-L. And they were building up Rabaul with troops and ships to come in.
and going to Port Moresby.
They had tried to land at Lay and go over the old Stanley Range.
And it was too steep and it was just jungle.
And they couldn't make it.
And then there was a lot of poisonous snakes and so forth.
So they gave up that idea that they're not going to go across the old Stanley Range.
It's a string of mountains.
and go by ship and take over more space and bypass everything else that's in between.
Okay.
Madame McArthur got the word, 22-ship convoy coming out of Rabaul.
Later it was refuted by Admiral Emmets, but there were six battleships.
I don't know exactly what they were, but they were cruisers and destroyers.
that were, they were escorting the troop ships.
And when Kenny got the word that they're on their way, he says, I want everything that can fly.
And man, I tell you, we were day and night loading up those planes.
And the Aussies, apparently the Aussies were the only ones that had these flying Catalinas.
He said, I want every Catalina up there to pick up our fliers if they're down.
OK?
And so I said, all right.
So our Air Force was already looking for them.
And they found them.
And they started bombing.
And there was a, I can't think of the man's name.
He was an officer in the Air Force with the Air Corps, and he was the one that, I say, I want to use the word, who invented skip bombing.
See?
Okay?
You know when you take a flat piece of rock and you toss it and it goes, okay.
And they got this, he had a squadron of B-25s.
And they used the B-25s that would come down just at,
just above the water.
And they'd spawn a troop ship and they would drop this bomb.
And let it bounce toward the troop ship.
Right, exactly.
And they had daisy cutters on the end.
Now a daisy cutter is a fuse.
The fuses that were used in the bombs were two types.
One that fit in the nose
want to fit in the tail.
If the fuse in the nose failed, the one in the back would discharge them.
Now, before some G.I.
decided there was a need to use these bombs for anti-personnel, and they wanted the bomb to explode above the ground.
And because when the bomb would hit the ground, it would go down maybe five or six feet, and then they would explode.
But the effect was not what they wanted.
So this guy decided, this G.I.
said, hey, why don't we extend that fuse?
And they called it a daisy cutter.
And when the bomb hits the ground, it'll go off above the ground.
And that's what they used on those bombs to hit the ship.
When they hit the ship, it made a gaping hole and the water rushed in.
And then there were another squadron of B-25s.
They had a 75-millimeter cannon in the nose, okay?
And just when you had the briefings, you know, they had 50 calibers.
on the side, and there were gates that where the tracers would meet would be 200 yards.
So whenever the tracers would cross on the target, they let the .25-mm cannon take off, and the recoil just slowed down the B-25.
Well, anyway, according
to the reports we got, the battle lasted about 20 minutes, and every ship was sunk.
Is this the Battle of the Coral Sea?
No.
The Battle of the Bismarck Sea.
Oh, Bismarck Sea.
3 March 1943.
Okay.
Now, the Navy was over there, close by, for support if they needed.
And you know when you
when the ship goes down.
There's always a lot of debris in the water, records, papers and stuff like that.
So, Battle of Nimitz boys, they picked up everything they could, see.
And MacArthur had already had a report prior to the battle that there was a 22-ship convoy.
Well, Nimitz's boys got a log that said, it's only 16.
So he brought it over to McCarthy and says, hey, you've been saying this is a 22-ship convoy.
You saw it.
You only saw 16.
And they got into a squabble.
And somebody in Washington told them to back off and leave McCarthy alone.
Do you know about that?
Oh, I tell you.
And so I left that one part about when the hostilities started, and General Kennedy came down.
they had a general there named Strademeyer.
And Strademeyer was, I can't think of a word to describe him, but he was kind of easy going, slow, and all he had was reconnaissance flights, that's all.
And when General Kennedy came over, he wanted to go back and fight the Nips.
And he ran into, Strademeyer was blocking it, I'll use that word.
And so General Kinney, he went on to MacArthur and said, look, I came over here to fight a war, and I want to get those nymphs home.
Are you going to let me run that air war, or are you going to let us spend them on her?
And the word was really out.
MacArthur never had anybody talk to him like that.
And he said, okay, George, take it over.
And he said, spend a mile back in the States or somewhere.
And he was out.
So General Kennedy took over everything.
And he was the one that had those 6x6s and 4x4 trucks cut and put half the front end in a C-47, fired up there, and then the other part in another plane.
And the people up in New Guinea,
those vehicles over here?
I don't see no boats coming in to unload them."
Oh, they walked down the road.
And back in Townsville, when the whacks came in, you know, the whacks, the women, and they were going to a big dance.
You don't have to put this down, but
the, the, the black G.I.s, they wanted to go out there and beat the whacks, see.
And they went over there, and the other Anglo G.I.s, they didn't want the black G.I.s to dance with us.
And it was a big fight, and they cut the dancers out.
We had to
at the airstrip.
We had a place where they had the planes parked, you know.
And some of those girls were over there.
And somebody said, you know what, I think those women were prostitutes before they got in there, because there was something going on over there on those parked planes.
Do you get my drift?
Okay.
And it was something, I tell you.
And well,
After this battle of the Bismarck Sea, that killed everything for the Japanese.
They couldn't get to Fort Moresby.
So finally they put us aboard LSTs and we went into Manila.
And we were at what used to be Clark Field.
And then there was Fort Stottsenburg.
It was messed up.
I mean, it was bombed and everything else.
And then there was Nichols Field.
Nichols Field was a smaller operation than Clark.
And so we were there, stationed at Clark, again setting up our ammunition, setting up
on top of small arms weapons.
And we hired, well we didn't do it, the quarter marshal did.
They hired work battalions of local people to police up the areas and do this and so forth.
And there was a group that could speak Spanish.
So I got around.
I was friends with them.
These were Filipinos?
Yes, Filipinos.
There were some girls that would come around with their brothers to pick up laundry.
And, you know, there's always a GI that wants to get, you know, put their hands on them and say, no, no, Filipino customs, no touch.
And there were trucks going back and forth for the unloading ships, the docks, back to camp.
And some of these Filipinos wanted to get someplace, and they would stand on the highway trying to get a ride.
But the GI wouldn't stop.
So these fellas says, you know, let's put the girl over there, and we hide in the bush.
And when he stopped, we jumped.
And we tell them, we tell them, we want the girl to sit over here with us in the front seat.
And that's the way they got, you know, go back and forth.
And let's see, then we have, when we got to Manila, then we went to Okinawa.
And let's see, Okinawa, we were, we had, when we wanted some fish, we'd go to the Quartermaster and get a duck.
A duck was one of those vehicles that looked like a boat.
You could go in the water.
And we wanted to go fish, but we didn't know where to fish, and we didn't know which were the good fish, because that was poisonous fish.
So we got one of the natives, and he had a sixth sense.
He could tell where the fish were.
So he says, that way, it's right here.
And we get hand grenades, see it?
And we throw them in the water.
And pretty soon, and that was the fish.
And we'd have a fish fry.
And we got an allowance of beer, six cans of beer a month.
And we didn't care who made the beer, just a little beer.
And how did you cool it?
Well, we had some ammunition boxes, all metal.
And we'd take, you remember those aerosol bombs for mosquitoes?
We put the cancer beer in there, and one of these pumped it up.
And hey, we closed the lid, and we had some cold beers.
Some were not satisfied.
They'd get some peaches or apple or something, let it ferment, you know, and they called it jungle juice, and then get drunk on that.
Well, anyway.
Where were you when you heard about the atom bomb?
Where were you when you heard about the atom bomb?
The atomic bomb?
Oh, the atom bomb.
Okay.
In Okinawa.
We were in Okinawa.
And we saw our first B-29.
And we thought it was a monster, see?
Because we were used to seeing P-38s and P-40s.
And the fighter pilots had a preference for P-38s because we said, hey, if we
If one of our engines goes out, we can come back on the other one.
We had a pilot named Richard Bong.
He flew P-38s.
He was a daring old fool.
And General Kenney grounded him.
He had 40 kills to his credit.
And he knew that he had hit others that probably didn't make it to their base, but they gave him credit for 40.
And someone says,
How is it that Bong can shoot so many airplanes while Neil Kirby and the other two were just way behind him?
He says, well, what he does, he flies right up to the plane and lets go of those 450s.
And he's taking too many chances because that Japanese pilot may have a wingman or something that'll come in.
Finally, they got Mr. Bong.
But we went back to the States, and he was found in one of the first jet planes.
And he crashed.
Garrett, with a lot, you have a call on line one.
Garrett, with a lot, you have a call on line one.
Oh.
And so when the atomic bomb was dropped and everything, they started releasing the guys that had the most time overseas.
Where did you all hear?
Where were you when you heard about that bomb being dropped?
Naha, Okinawa.
And what was your reaction?
What did you all think?
Was it a surprise?
Well, yes, we were surprised and we were happy because now we're going home.
And who's going home?
The guys that have been here the most, the longest.
With the point system?
Yeah, point system.
So when did you get back to San Antonio?
That's a good question.
The twenty-fifth day of October, 1945.
That's right.
And you started back to work when?
Well, let me see.
I didn't start back to work goodnight.
It must have been
In late January.
Of 46?
Yeah.
And what job did you get?
The same job I had before.
And so they were, it was still the same old place, but there was a shortage of parts.
I remember that.

And, but, yeah, now, Mr. Feeble was just glad to get me back, and he, you see, the veterans, if you recall, they would give them preference to give them their old jobs back, see, and I just fit it in, just.
When did you meet this special young lady?
Well, that's another story.
When I was up there at Payne Field,
there was this fellow, Richard Bazan.
And of course, going up there to Everett, Washington, there was hardly any Hispanics over there.
And in our company, we had, let's see, one, two, three, three.
And one of them, two of them were from San Antonio, one from Beeville.
And this fellow, I forget his name now, he was real dark, and he could pass for an Indian.
So when we go to Town Hall Pass,
somebody, oh, I'll stop at some bridge, you know, and get a couple of beers.
And the bartender will look at this guy, and he refused to serve him beer, because he says, in Washington, it's against the law to sell beer to Indians.
No, he's not.
So one of us had to buy the beer, didn't give it to him.
He says, don't let him see you drinking it.
Okay.
So, uh, the, uh, uh, Mr. Feller, Richard Poisson from Bealeville,
on mail calling, he would get letters, you see, and here I am, and nobody was writing to me.
And so I was the same.
You recall, there was the newspapers building up to promote pen pals.
You don't know them, but they write, tell you what's going on at home.
So they gave me five names, and I wrote to the girls.
Hey, I got some answers.
It was fine.
And this kept up.
Finally,
Four of them kind of slowed down, you know, and they quit.
But Rachel, my wife, she kept on riding.
All during the war, she kept on riding, answering my rail.
And you had not seen her yet?
No.
We were strangers.
And she had an aunt in San Antonio that she would visit on.
And I said, would you give my mother a call or visit with her and tell her that we're riding and I'm OK?
So that kind of gave her some sense of relief
Yes.
So she'd go over there and visit with my mother.
So when I came home, you see, I said, I got to meet that lady and thank her for what she'd done and for writing to me and all this, you see.
And that was all.
I was going to say thank you, goodbye, but something happened there, you see.
I can't describe it.
When I started to get off the bus,
I said, you know, I like what I see.
And so I took her out.
First I went to see her aunt and get her blessings, you know, that they would allow for me to take her out and suffer.
I brought her back in a decent hour.
And I would visit with her when she would come to.
Or I would, I had to borrow a car.
from the company, you know, as an old 41 Chevrolet.
And I'd drive all the way to Beville, which was about 90 miles from San Antonio.
And I'd go there and visit with them.
And so one thing led to the other, you know.
And so I asked her to marry me, and she said yes.
When did you all get married?
Fifteenth day of December, 1945.
Forty-five or six?
Forty-five.
This was a quick thing now.
Oh, okay.
See, because I got out in October.
Okay.
October the 25th.
So you got married in less than two months.
Yeah.
And so I had heard gossip, Richard's getting married, it won't last.
She hardly knows the boy, and vice versa.
Well, it was something because the other girls, her sisters, she had five sisters, and they got married, and their marriages broke up except on one.
They sold it together.
But on our marriage, they didn't give it, we said, it's not going to last.
So she moved to San Antonio.
and you continued your job, and then what caused you to start thinking about going to college?
Well, I knew General Motors parts like an open book.
I had a good memory to remember, and you know, every year when the new models come in,
They always, something goes wrong, the heat indicator doesn't work, the speedometer doesn't work, or whatever.
There's a defective part, and under the warranty that's placed on the car, the dealer's supposed to replace it, see?
And then the dealer would get it back to these defective parts and sends them back to the factory and gets...
